item.title: From a Barossa 'baronial' background, Ashton Hurn has risen to the SA Liberal leadership
item.description: South Australia's new opposition leader Ashton Hurn has likened the task ahead of her to climbing a mountain, but she's taking inspiration from a family background that includes a former state cricketer and an AFL premiership captain.

item.title: Why Kate chose to 'stay flat' after breast cancer surgery
item.description: After a cancer diagnosis, Kate Miller's doctor recommended a mastectomy on one side only. But Kate wanted both breasts gone.

item.title: Beetaloo Basin gas piped north to 'keep the lights on' in NT from 2026
item.description: The gas-rich Beetaloo Basin in the Northern Territory has been in development for years — now, the NT government says the gas will finally flow from 2026.

item.title: Abuse survivors say Centrelink's 'couple rule' puts women in danger
item.description: Financial and domestic abuse survivors say the way Centrelink assesses benefit payments for people in a relationship makes it harder for women to leave dangerous relationships.

item.title: Rare brain illness could not stop Milly from making country netball history
item.description: A rare brain illness left Milly Brock unable to walk or speak, but eight months later, she was back leading her regional netball club on grand final day.

item.title: Why Ashton Hurn may, or may not, succeed as SA Liberal leader
item.description: Ashton Hurn now has the job she said she didn't want. Could she be the leader the South Australian Liberal Party needs?

item.title: Iron deficiency is a challenge for many female athletes, like Super Netball's Zara Walters
item.description: Zara Walters felt tired, dizzy and unable to recover from training sessions — then she found out she was low in iron. It's a condition that often goes undiagnosed, especially in female athletes.

item.title: ASIO examined Bondi Beach gunman Naveed Akram in 2019 for close ties to Islamic State cell
item.description: Australia's domestic intelligence agency, ASIO, examined one of the Bondi Beach gunmen six years ago for his close ties to a Sydney-based Islamic State terrorism cell, the ABC understands.

item.title: Bondi Beach gunmen's movements in Philippines under investigation by local police
item.description: Philippines National Police say they are investigating whether the father-son Bondi gunmen travelled to a region known as a hotbed for violent Islamist militants.

item.title: Nearly 600 trees to be lost for North Adelaide's public course redevelopment for LIV Golf event
item.description: The South Australian government has released plans for North Adelaide's public golf course redevelopment confirming that nearly 600 trees will be cut down, not the thousands previously claimed by the Liberals.

item.title: How to turn feelings of helplessness into support after the Bondi attack
item.description: While you might be feeling a sense of helplessness after the attack at Bondi Beach, there are ways to convert those feelings into small acts of support and kindness.

item.title: Is 2025 ending with an AI bubble? We could be at a turning point in history
item.description: What makes the AI-driven stock market bubble unique in history is that if it's not a bubble, the impact on humanity could be far more challenging than any previous technology.

item.title: Building a village means showing up even when it feels hard, says Esther Perel
item.description: Building and maintaining a village doesn't just happen. It takes effort. It means showing up even when it feels hard or inconvenient, says psychotherapist Esther Perel.

item.title: WA farming community loses 500 sheep, thousands of hectares of crops in fire
item.description: A bushfire emergency in Warradarge is over, but farmers say the work to recover what was lost has only just begun.

item.title: 'Aussie' poster in Adelaide vandalised with white supremacist message
item.description: An Adelaide street artist's poster aimed at provoking thought about national identity has been vandalised with racist graffiti.

item.title: When can you get a refund or exchange under Australian law?
item.description: It can feel awkward asking for a refund or to exchange an item if you’re not sure what you’re entitled to. We’ve broken it down.

item.title: Today in History: Top-secret Manhattan Project quietly approved
item.description: On December 28, 1942, a US president formally approved an investment in the top-secret project to create nuclear weapons.

item.title: LGBTQIA+ focused boxing class combatting loneliness amid warnings about social isolation
item.description: One in three adults experience social isolation in what experts say is a "dangerous" issue in society. One suburban boxing group is working to tackle the issue, focused on the LGBTQIA+ community more at risk of loneliness.

item.title: South Australian MP Nick McBride to remain in custody for next seven days
item.description: South Australian independent MP Nick McBride will spend the next week in custody, after being arrested and charged over the weekend.

item.title: Human-operated Tokyo robot venture allows housebound people to work
item.description: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

item.title: Record year for Australian beef exports despite Donald Trump's tariffs
item.description: When Donald Trump enforced a 10 per cent tariff on Australian beef, there were some concerns it would impact trade. But the opposite happened.

item.title: NSW residents urged to check if they are owed share of $300m in unclaimed cash
item.description: Almost $300 million in refunds, dividends and cheques remain unclaimed by households and businesses across New South Wales, with locals urged to take action to secure the money they are owed.

item.title: Assault-accused MP Nick McBride says home detention makes him 'more wedded' to electorate
item.description: South Australian MP Nick McBride, who has been charged with aggravated assault, says home detention will make him "more focused" on his electorate ahead of the SA election in March.

item.title: Nick McBride could get $100k in taxpayer funding for re-election campaign
item.description: Independent MP Nick McBride, who is currently on home detention bail for the alleged assault of his wife, could receive around $100,000 in public funding to support his re-election campaign, according to the state's electoral commission.

item.title: Supporting your child when starting child care or kindy
item.description: It's natural to feel nervous about transitioning your baby or child into early childhood education. Knowing some settling techniques, as well as what you can advocate for on behalf of your child, can help their transition.

item.title: How I have fun with friends without spending money
item.description: I've kept low-cost, high-fun habits alive for years, even after returning home to a city where socialising often seems to mean shelling out.

item.title: Explosives used to demolish Bell Bay power station smokestack
item.description: It took just 41 kilograms of explosives and less than a minute — a remnant of the 1970s fossil fuel age is blown to bits to make way for a methanol fuel plant.

item.title: Adelaide Writers' Week cancelled amid controversy over disinvitation of author Randa Abdel-Fattah
item.description: The remaining members of the Adelaide Festival board will step down and this year's Writers' Week event has been cancelled, after days of furore regarding the decision to cancel a scheduled appearance by Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah.

item.title: Writers' Week cancellation highlights SA premier's uneasy relationship with the arts
item.description: After backing the Adelaide Festival's decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author from Writers' Week, Peter Malinauskas is now trying to distance himself from a crisis that threatens to do untold damage to South Australia's festival reputation.

item.title: United Employment collapse leaves disability workers $6 million short in missing pay, super and entitlements
item.description: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

item.title: Cross-cultural sharing is at the heart of Townsville's community garden
item.description: In the heart of north Queensland, Ukrainians, Fijians, Zimbabweans and Koreans gather in the dirt to help each other grow vegetables.

item.title: Have you been gifted an ancestry DNA test? The results could be 'life-altering'
item.description: If you're thinking of taking an ancestry DNA test as "a bit of fun", experts warn there is the risk of uncovering more than you bargained for.

item.title: Back-to-school budgeting a chance for kids to learn financial literacy and empathy
item.description: Managing back-to-school costs, especially when kids want expensive brand name items, can cause a lot of stress for families. But including children in the budgeting and decision-making process is key to helping everyone get on the same page.

item.title: City of Perth probe lays bare workplace 'crisis', erosion of trust between Mayor and CEO
item.description: The City of Perth has rapidly descended into a workplace of psychological harm, according to a secret report obtained by the ABC.

item.title: David Speirs not entitled to public campaign funding, electoral commission says
item.description: Former opposition leader David Speirs would "not fulfil the nomination requirements" if he applied to be a candidate at the upcoming state election, the state's electoral commission says, raising significant doubts about his chances of a political comeback.

item.title: triple j's Hottest 100 of 2025 — when it happens, how to listen and more
item.description: Australia's favourite music poll is back for another year — here's when it happens and how to listen.

item.title: As Russia's war intensifies Europe is exploring military and economic independence
item.description: As the world's elite gathered in Davos, European leaders confronted a reality in which they might need to defend themselves, and potentially against, the United States.

item.title: Quick and easy pasta with a zesty, no-cook salsa sauce - ABC News
item.description: Salsa is not just for tacos. It's the perfect summer pasta sauce and makes the most of juicy summer tomatoes.

item.title: Hoping to start your finances afresh in 2026? These tips will help
item.description: It might be time to devote some of your energy and good intentions towards your finances.

item.title: Why time feels like it speeds up as we age
item.description: The perception that time is flying by can sometimes make us feel stressed and anxious. So how do we slow it down?

item.title: Planning to breastfeed? Preparation can help you meet your goals
item.description: While most mothers in Australia start breastfeeding, by the time babies are five months old, exclusive breastfeeding drops to 15 per cent. Knowing what to expect — before bub is born — can increase the chances of meeting your breastfeeding goals.

item.title: Albanese government urged to use careful diplomacy to defuse Darwin Port row with China
item.description: Industry groups that suffered three years of damaging Chinese trade tariffs on products including barley are appealing to the federal government to exercise careful diplomacy to defuse tensions with China over the ownership of Darwin Port.

item.title: Tyra Banks's 'hot ice cream' went viral. Don't expect to see it called that anymore
item.description: Reviews have said it "tasted like soggy biscuits" and was "a weird sensation to sip through a straw". Taste aside, something bugged me. How can you call something ice cream if it's not iced?

item.title: A 'chia seed' trend on TikTok promotes a 'quick fix' to weight loss, but is it safe?
item.description: The health benefits of chia seeds have been well publicised, but health and internet experts are urging people to not believe everything you see on social media.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz has his never-before moment by beating Novak Djokovic in his own house
item.description: Carlos Alcaraz has defeated Novak Djokovic in a pulsating Australian Open final, becoming the youngest man with a career Grand Slam in the process.

item.title: Alcaraz and Djokovic thrill Rafa and a 'boring' heckle delights Rod Laver Arena — quick hits from the Australian Open men's final

item.title: From Sabalenka to Djokovic and 'animals in the zoo', here are the best quotes from the Australian Open 2026
item.description: From tennis stars pushing for more privacy, to Djokovic saying he feels like an old man and a Kyrgios F-bomb, there have been some funny and weird quotes at this year's Australian Open.

item.title: Back to school for Northern Territory construction workers after Charles Darwin University blunder
item.description: Dozens of carpentry apprentices in the Northern Territory will be forced back to TAFE after an error saw them declared qualified to work on construction projects without completing required units of study.

item.description: A 47-year-old worker has died following an incident at the Tanami gold mine in remote Central Australia, with police and NT WorkSafe investigating.

item.title: Diamonds defeat Jamaica in first netball Test match in Adelaide
item.description: The Diamonds made a flying start with the initial six goals in a comprehensive 72-41 victory at the Adelaide Entertainment Centre.

item.title: Today in history, February 6: The Manchester United team that perished in the Munich air disaster of 1958
item.description: On a snowy February afternoon in 1958, the football team that many were calling the greatest that Britain had ever produced stopped to refuel at Munich Airport. The plane would never take off, and the Flowers of Manchester would take years to bloom again.

item.title: What Israel's President Isaac Herzog has said about Gaza, and why he won't be arrested in Australia
item.description: When Israel's president lands in Australia this weekend, he can expect an official red carpet treatment. But he will be all too aware of the controversy his visit is generating.

item.title: ATO debt continues to drive record level of calls to small business financial helpline
item.description: Financial counsellors say small businesses struggling to pay debts owed to the tax office are driving calls to Australia's Small Business Debt Helpline higher.

item.title: French authorities sink tonnes of cocaine bound for Australia, then release suspects
item.description: French authorities intercept a ship carrying five tonnes of cocaine bound for Australia, before releasing the vessel and its crew.

item.title: Gus Lamont's grandparents 'absolutely devastated' by major crime declaration
item.description: The grandparents of missing four-year-old boy Gus Lamont say the family has "cooperated fully with the investigation and want nothing more than to find Gus and reunite him with his mum and dad".

item.title: Indonesia's government directs education funds to meals program as teachers struggle on low wages
item.description: Temporary teachers in Indonesia paid low wages criticise a government decision to direct one third of yearly education funding to the president's flagship free meals program.

item.description: Martin Luther King Jr's son says while the US administration was "attempting to turn the clock back" on equal rights, Australia shows "potential".

item.description: As Adelaide Writers' Week went up in flames, Julian Hobba contemplated resigning as Adelaide Festival's executive director. He now says "we needed to trust the judgement" of the literary event's former leader, Louise Adler.

item.description: As the last man standing, 78-year-old cattleman Mervyn has parted with his collection of tractors and utes, pledging his estate to charity.

item.description: The infamous Isabel Gray was known by many names and fronted court for sly grogging and stood accused of running a brothel.

item.description: After Donald Trump's repeated threats to acquire Greenland, many Danish people felt powerless but new apps are helping them make choices to boycott US-made products.

item.description: The barge drifted into Australian waters from Indonesia after breaking from its moorings during bad weather.

item.description: One Nation questions if man-made climate change is real, wants to wind back access to abortion care and plans to pay the HECS debts of doctors working in the regions.

item.description: The debris balls that have washed up on NSW beaches in recent years are likely to continue as Sydney Water admits a massive fatberg it cannot reach is clogging sewers.

item.description: Four Corners is the home of Australian investigative journalism.

item.description: Spears is the latest music star to sell the rights to their work, a decade after the release of her ninth and last studio album.

item.description: Festival Tower Two is set to tower over South Australia's Parliament House, which the premier says will bring money and people into the city, but others remain against the $800 million project.

item.description: The rural-based social program in the shadow of Mt Tamborine has had remarkable success in rebuilding the lives of youth who have fallen through the cracks.

item.description: Tradies are walking out. Not over ability or aptitude but toilets — in a symbol of the sector's persistent barriers.

item.description: British economist Gary Stevenson is on a speaking tour, warning Australia will follow the path of the UK with "poverty exploding" unless politicians deal with inequality.

item.title: Hindmarsh Island bridge dispute told through Ngarrindjeri women's art
item.description: In the 1990s, a group of Indigenous women were accused of fabricating claims of sacred sites to stop the construction of a bridge south of Adelaide. It was a decision that has impacted a community for decades.

item.title: Eungella residents want an alternative exit after Cyclone Koji cuts the range road again
item.description: The remote mountain community of Eungella was cut off for the second time in three years after Cyclone Koji brought debris down on the range road. After years of inaction, the community want more options when severe weather strikes again.

item.description: The One Nation leader qualified her earlier remarks, which had been met with condemnation, while reiterating calls for tougher vetting processes for Muslim migrants.

item.title: Australia's most successful Winter Olympics coach Peter McNiel and how his moguls team led the Milano Cortina gold rush

item.title: Housing to play part in future of both old and new ABC sites in Adelaide
item.description: The ABC's managing director says its current Adelaide bureau could be redeveloped in a similar way to an apartment building nearby, while the premier says affordable apartments will still be included on the new CBD site.

item.title: As Donald Trump's first Board of Peace meeting approaches, Indonesians are watching their own president closely
item.description: Ahead of the inaugural meeting of US President Donald Trump's Board of Peace, charged with leading the way forward in Gaza, Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto faces perhaps his most significant foreign policy test yet.

item.title: Is it ever a good idea to stay together for the kids?
item.description: When a relationships breaks down, sometimes we think staying in the familiar discomfort is less scary — and even protective — for our kids. But is it ever a good idea to stay in an unhappy relationship for the sake of the children?

item.title: Chalmers suggests ex-RBA governor's spending critique is due to personal vendetta
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says Philip Lowe was critical of the government over spending because it did not re-appoint him as RBA governor.

item.title: Mazda, Nissan, Hyundai and Subaru face multi-million-dollar penalties under NVES
item.description: Major car brands are staring down the barrel of multi-million-dollar penalties for exceeding their emissions, the first results of the federal government's climate laws for new vehicles have revealed.

item.title: Workers in cherry picker help police catch man accused of lewd acts in Goulburn
item.description: A man is accused of intimidation and carrying out a sexual act over incidents at a medical reception and childcare centre.

item.title: Police treating spate of Western Sydney shootings and arson attacks as linked
item.description: Raptor Squad detectives are treating three separate incidents as linked to a conflict between two organised criminal networks.

item.title: Footage shows gunman spraying bullets into suburban home
item.description: Follow the latest headlines from ABC News, Australia's most trusted media source, with live events, audio and on-demand video from the national broadcaster.

item.title: Wednesday finance with Alan Kohler
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Terrorism comes to Invasion Day rally in Perth
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: Police accused of being slow to respond to alleged homemade bomb at Perth Invasion Day rally
item.description: When Sisonke picked up a device that looked like a glass jar in Perth on Australia Day, she had a sense of foreboding so she took it to police. She says they took some time to act.

item.title: Tackling 'blatant' fake discounting, restoring consumer trust among ACCC's priorities for 2026
item.description: ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb outlines the consumer watchdog's priorities for 2026, including targeting "blatant" fake discounting.

item.title: Ukraine reclaims more than 200 square kilometres of territory as Elon Musk blocks Russian army's internet access
item.description: Ukraine has made its largest battlefield gains in more than two and a half years, retaking more than 200 square kilometres of its territory from Russia in just five days, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Antarctic pioneer John King Davis's grave was unmarked – until now
item.description: Captain John King Davis was one of Australia's greatest Antarctic explorers, but for decades, his final resting place was an unmarked grave in Melbourne. Today, that will change.

item.title: Today in History, February 19: Britpop, beats and a lust for life on Trainspotting's deathless soundtrack
item.description: Most films are lucky to get just one needle-drop moment embedded in the Zeitgeist. Trainspotting boasted several.

item.title: Quiz: Which books are these literary quotes from?
item.description: Are you happiest with your nose in a book? Did you spend summer reading at the beach? This quiz is for you.

item.title: Government spending is creeping up and threatening Australia’s 'low-debt' status
item.description: Australia will cease to be a low-debt country and be more vulnerable in a future crisis without a combination of spending restraint and tax reform, a new report has warned.

item.title: Senate committee features climate disinformation, the Atlas Network, and Dr Karl's clash with One Nation
item.description: The scourge of AI-slopaganda, viral disinformation campaigns and online attacks against individuals and institutions is going to get far worse before it gets better, if the latest public hearings on the topic are any indication.

item.title: Perth couple Jonathan and Amy Carr-Knox locked in international surrogacy battle to bring home daughter
item.description: Jonathan and Amy had a child via surrogacy in Argentina. They have been stuck there for 12 months, unable to bring their daughter home.

item.title: Could SA Liberal leader Ashton Hurn lose her seat at the next election?
item.description: It's an almost unthinkable scenario, but the fact it's even being discussed shows the extent of the Liberal Party's predicament.

item.title: Fiji's former prime minister Frank Bainimarama charged with inciting mutiny
item.description: Long-serving Fiji prime minister Frank Bainimarama and a former police commissioner will face court on Tuesday on charges of mutiny.

item.title: Unemployment steady, ASX just misses record close, energy stocks bounce on oil spike — as it happened
item.description: A steady unemployment rate puts more pressure on interest rates, while solid company results and higher oil prices push the ASX to a near record close

item.title: Moyne Shire Council never wanted Port Fairy's pool, yet it paid $3.4m for it
item.description: A Victorian community group promised its local shire a new pool would not cost it money once it was built. In less than three months, the promise was broken.

item.title: James and Sophie among West Australians keen to give back as regional doctors
item.description: After graduating six years apart at the same high school in Kalgoorlie, both James Gent and Sophie Barton are following their dream of becoming a doctor.

item.title: Indian university kicked out of summit for falsely claiming credit for Chinese-made robotic dog
item.description: An Indian professor has sparked ridicule after falsely suggesting a commercially available Chinese robot dog displayed at a major AI summit in New Delhi was developed by her university.

item.title: From crime heists to a BDSM love story, here's what's in cinemas this month
item.description: Australians will also finally be able to catch Sirât and The Voice of Hind Rajab, two movies that will be vying for Best International Film at the Academy Awards next month.

item.title: Brisbane's Lang Park concert cap almost doubles under new trial
item.description: A one-year trial will see the number of concerts at Brisbane's Lang Park almost double from 12 to 21 per year.

item.title: How exclusion orders could ban Australian citizens from returning home indefinitely
item.description: One of the Australian women being held in a Syrian refugee camp has been barred from returning home after being given a temporary exclusion order — but the ban may not be as temporary as the name implies.

item.title: SA secures Australian MotoGP, world-first street circuit announced
item.description: The South Australian government has confirmed the Australian MotoGP will move to Adelaide from 2027, bringing with it huge economic benefits, but the opposition and Greens say the state has other priorities.

item.title: Feed and water supplies dry up in NSW as drought tightens grip
item.description: Over this season's hot and dry summer in New South Wales, farmer Ryan Staniforth has spent much of his time carting water to keep his sheep alive.

item.title: Charlie Pickering on his ADHD, satire and the 'ludicrous' Trump era
item.description: Political satire occasionally comes at a price, but Charlie Pickering still believes the right joke at the right time can have a huge impact.

item.title: The heartwarming tribute to injured aerials star Laura Peel at the Winter Olympics
item.description: This Winter Olympics aerials competition saw plenty of Aussies achieve lifetime goals, but they never forgot the one person who was missing — injured champion Laura Peel.

item.title: Wayne Gardner, Casey Stoner slam Victorian government over Phillip Island MotoGP loss
item.description: Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix winner Wayne Gardner has lashed out at the Victorian government over the loss of the Phillip Island MotoGP, saying he has been left "disappointed" and "sad" by the decision.

item.title: Police commissioner claims drones over Moree will not be used for surveillance
item.description: Police will control drones from more than 600 kilometres away from a rural town battling high crime rates.

item.title: Heavy rain through north Queensland leads to multiple floodwater rescues and Bruce Highway closures
item.description: Heavy rainfall across north Queensland has led to multiple rescues and the closure of several sections of the Bruce Highway.

item.title: Sydney businessman compiled reports for what he allegedly believed was Chinese intelligence, court hears
item.description: A LinkedIn introduction led to Australian businessman Alexander Csergo compiling reports for two people he believed worked for a Chinese intelligence agency in exchange for cash, a jury has heard.

item.title: In her memoir, Gisèle Pelicot reveals the secret love behind France's most infamous rape trial
item.description: The world knows Gisèle Pelicot as the woman who waived anonymity during France's most infamous rape trial. But in her new memoir she reveals an unexpected story — the boyfriend she kept hidden and the love that helped her face an open courtroom.

item.title: Rescue team departs to the site of avalanche in California's Sierra Nevada mountains
item.description: Follow the latest headlines from ABC News, Australia's most trusted media source, with live events, audio and on-demand video from the national broadcaster.

item.title: An avalanche in Northern California was the worst in the US for 40 years. Here's how it unfolded
item.description: An avalanche in California has left eight back-country skiers dead and one missing. Here's how it unfolded.

item.title: Rugby fans furious over 2027 Rugby World Cup ticket website crashes
item.description: Rugby fans from around the world are furious after failing to get tickets to the 2027 Men's World Cup due technical glitches and website crashes.

item.title: For salty South Australians, motorsport revenge is oh so sweet
item.description: The last Grand Prix in Adelaide was held in 1995 before its move across the border to Victoria. Now, Adelaide has poached the MotoGP — but will it be enough to appease resentful SA Formula One fans?

item.title: Hate laws put free speech at risk, constitutional expert tells NSW extremism inquiry
item.description: An influx of federal and state laws trying to curb hateful rhetoric after a wave of antisemitic attacks are risking free speech and could anger the public, a constitutional law expert warns.

item.title: Man charged with terrorism offences after phones seized in Sydney's south-west
item.description: A 31-year-old has been arrested a second time after police stopped and searched a vehicle in Yagoona and seized three mobile phones allegedly storing violent extremist material.

item.title: Free RSV flu vaccine for aged care residents to be rolled out in WA
item.description: After a horror flu season last year, free RSV vaccinations are being rolled out for the first time for older Western Australians living in residential aged care.

item.title: Canberra schoolboys face drug-affected driver who struck them outside St Edmund's College
item.description: Tayler Hazell is facing his victims in a sentencing hearing in the ACT Supreme Court. He struck two students in Canberra in a stolen car while high on drugs.

item.title: Hanson digs her heels in, Taylor goes on tour
item.description: This week, the new opposition leader revealed his shadow cabinet while Pauline Hanson spun through a cycle she knows well.

item.title: Vegetable scraps to be turned into bioenergy by Scenic Rim farm as part of $291 million project
item.description: A new $291 million project set to turn farm scraps to energy has begun construction in Queensland's Scenic Rim.

item.title: Tracking the US military build-up ahead of possible Iran attack
item.description: The steady flow of military assets moving towards Europe and the Middle East appears to be a warning that the US could be ready to attack Iran.

item.title: What is Skimo? The sport preparing to steal the show at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympic Games
item.description: Skimo, or ski mountaineering, is coming to the 2026 Winter Olympics. But what is the sport and why is it so exciting?

item.title: Two WA childcare providers fined after high-needs children wander off from care
item.description: One of Australia's biggest providers of before-and-after-school care penalised after a five-year-old neurodivergent child escapes supervision unnoticed.

item.title: Court hears statement murdered woman Irma Palasics made after harrowing assault a year earlier
item.description: A statement made by murdered woman Irma Palasics after a burglary at her home a year prior is read to the ACT Supreme Court.

item.title: Racing NSW disqualifies stablehand and owner Brian Carey over racehorse death in Maryborough
item.description: Registered owner and stablehand Brian Carey is disqualified after being found guilty by Racing NSW of failing to ensure his racehorse, City Limits, had sufficient food and water.

item.title: Long-awaited rapid bus plan fails to reveal construction timeline or routes
item.description: After about a year of delays, the Tasmanian government has released its strategic business case for the Greater Hobart Rapid Bus Network, but a lot of the detail has not been included.

item.title: Salmon farm antibiotics found in native Tasmanian species kilometres away
item.description: An antibiotic used by the Tasmanian salmon farming industry is detected in native species more than 10km away from the closest fish operation using it.

item.title: Man accused of 'controlling' the lives of Venezuelan youth group granted bail
item.description: An alleged religious leader accused of "controlling every aspect" of the lives of a Venezuelan youth group has been granted release on strict home detention conditions by a South Australian court.

item.title: SA Premier Peter Malinauskas criticised over aged care workforce comments
item.description: South Australia's Premier Peter Malinauskas has been criticised across the political divide for comments he made asking One Nation voters "who's going to feed you and bathe you and wipe your bum when you're 90", but a government spokesperson says the comments have been mischaracterised.

item.title: Police investigate stabbing of 17-year-old at Geelong shopping mall
item.description: A 17-year-old boy has been taken to hospital with serious injuries after a suspected stabbing at the Market Square shopping centre in Geelong.

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026 quick guide: What to watch on Day 13
item.description: Find out what's on at the Winter Olympics in Milan.

item.title: Collingwood apologises after asking elderly members for donations via their wills
item.description: The Magpies have come under fire after a letter campaign asking elderly members to amend their wills to donate to the AFL club.

item.title: Coles manager moved product onto 'Down Down' promotion days after price hike to be more competitive
item.description: A second Coles manager has been grilled in the federal court over whether rushing a product onto a "Down Down" promotion could have broken internal guidelines.

item.title: South Korea's ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced to life in prison over insurrection
item.description: Former South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol is sentenced to life in prison on charges of rebellion for his attempt to put the country under military rule.

item.title: Rottnest Channel Swim organisers weigh cancellation as 55 kph winds forecast
item.description: As thousands of people prepare to tackle Western Australia's iconic Rottnest Island Swim, rough weather is threatening to grind it to a halt just 48 hours before it begins.

item.title: Labor Opposition, crossbench call for NT MLA Tanzil Rahman to respond to bullying allegations
item.description: An MLA accused of bullying by two female staffers is urged to front the public and explain what action has been taken following the claims.

item.title: Gas explosion kills 16 after apartment building partially collapses in southern Pakistan
item.description: Women and children are among 16 people killed after a gas explosion ripped through an apartment building in Pakistan on Thursday.

item.title: Greg Lynn applies for bail as retrial for High Country camper murder looms
item.description: The former Jetstar pilot awaits a retrial for the murder of Carol Clay, after his 2024 conviction was quashed in December.

item.title: Live: Aussies among first competitors in newest Olympic sport
item.description: Skimo, the newest sport at the Winter Olympics, makes its grand arrival in Milan Cortina, while Australia's teenage sensation Indra Brown hits the half-pipe. Follow live.

item.title: Hundreds commemorate the Bombing of Darwin on 84th anniversary
item.description: Eighty-four years after Darwin was bombed in the largest single foreign attack on Australian soil, hundreds have gathered to remember.

item.title: Employees of Albany lolly shop fined for illegal tobacco sales say they were never paid
item.description: "Vulnerable" staff at a smoke shop disguised as a candy store in Albany say they were never paid by the shop's mystery operators.

item.title: Coles’ Down Down’ pricing in the spotlight
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.
